titleStmt.title: Description of University of Manchester Library, Hebrew MS 23: Sefer ha-Mivhar, or Commentary on the Pentateuch

notesStmt.note: Some marginal notes in different hands.

msContents.summary: A manuscript copy of Aaron ben Joseph the Doctor's thirteenth-century commentary on the Pentateuch, known as "The Choice Book" (Sefer ha-Mivhar) or "Commentary on the Pentateuch". The title used in the manuscript is Sefer ha-Mivhar ve-Tuv ha-Mishar. Referred to as Aaron the Elder in some manuscripts, the author was deeply influenced by Maimonides' Guide for the Perplexed. He is believed to be the first Karaite to have injected Maimonidean ideas into Karaite mainstream thought.

msItem.title: Sefer ha-Mivhar, or Commentary on the Pentateuch
msItem.author: Aaron ben Joseph, ha-Rofe, -1320

respStmt.persName: Crawford, James Ludovic Lindsay, Earl of, 1847-1913

msItem.colophon: Running head on side a of each folio with the name of each parashah until the beginning of Parashat be-Midbar (Num. 1:1-4:20). Afterwards, running heads only appear sporadically, mostly in relation to Parashat Qorah (Num. 16:1-18:32). On folio 2b the commentary opens with a poem. The last line of the poem includes the date of composition, 1294.

msItem.title: Handwritten in pencil: Codex Caraiticus and 7.7.0.
Sefer ha-Mivhar. Four-word heading with dots over each letter. The commentary opens with a poem.
msItem.incipit: בני אל חי בני אבות ברורים

msItem.title: Handwritten notes in pencil reading Hebrew MSS / No. 23; W.H. Black / 16/6/57 and some notes on the content of the manuscript.

support.watermark: Circle with bull inside and a star next to the circle (f.iii).

supportDesc.foliation: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals at the bottom outer corner of side a of each folio, up to folio 31.

layoutDesc.layout: Long line with 38 written lines. Dry stylus ruling and bordering. Written dimensions: 228 x 153 mm.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Karaite semi-cursive script. Parashah beginnings and endings in Karaite square script.

decoDesc.decoNote: The initial words are made in black ink and have a wavy character. Each catchword is provided with a small wavy line. Successive inverted triangles and diamond shapes can be seen at the end of texts, such as the parashiyot (see e.g. folios 37a, 84b, 162b). Nearly every page has margin words that are marked with arrow-functional drawings: short pen strokes with a small circle at one end. They also occur in the text. Some additional decorations or peculiarities include: a four-word heading with dots over each letter (f.2b); manicules (f.4a; f.60b); and headings decorated in small ink stripes (ff.127a-128b).
127aHeadings are decorated with small ink stripes.
127bHeadings are decorated with small ink stripes.
128aHeadings are decorated with small ink stripes.
128bHeadings are decorated with small ink stripes.

binding.p: Cardboard flexible binding with grey paper cover. Sewn on two raised cords.

history.provenance: Acquired by Enriqueta Rylands in 1901 from James Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford of Haigh Hall, and later bequeathed to the John Rylands Library.
